topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Jiaona Zhang (JZ), her roles (Webflow SVP Product, Stanford lecturer), and what they’ll cover: PM mistakes, minimal lovable products, roadmaps/OKRs, WeWork lessons, and Airbnb Plus.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for Brave Search API and Miro, including listener links and product value props.

topics.title: Common mistakes new PMs make
topics.summary: JZ shares what she most often has to “unteach” new PMs: jumping to solutions and getting attached to an implementation instead of deeply understanding user problems and opportunities first.

topics.title: PM authority myths and influence reality
topics.summary: They discuss why many people enter PM expecting CEO-like authority, and JZ explains PM success depends on influence, alignment, and editing options—not calling shots.

topics.title: Biggest product mistake: Airbnb Plus
topics.summary: JZ reflects on Airbnb Plus as a solution-first, competitor-driven initiative that leaned into operations-heavy inspection, misfit with Airbnb’s strengths and unclear unit economics.

topics.title: Dream big but validate execution and milestones
topics.summary: They explore when ambitious vision works versus when to “do the math,” with JZ advocating explicit learning phases, unscalable prototypes, and clear go/no-go milestones to avoid sunk-cost traps.

topics.title: How to push back on founder-led ideas
topics.summary: JZ explains how to disagree effectively: build conviction, align on the underlying goal (“spirit”), and bring better options backed by data and scalable approaches.

topics.title: Minimal lovable product versus MVP
topics.summary: JZ defines minimal lovable product as meeting a quality bar that users will genuinely enjoy, noting the bar depends on alternatives (e.g., spreadsheets) and user expectations (e.g., designers vs finance).

topics.title: Webflow example and what makes products lovable
topics.summary: Using Webflow features (memberships/logic), JZ discusses deciding whether to rely on ecosystem for “lovable” layers, focusing on doing fewer things exceptionally well, and adding selective “pixie dust” like shortcuts/templates.

topics.title: Roadmapping: tell themes and a story
topics.summary: JZ argues roadmaps should communicate narrative and themes rather than spreadsheet-driven scoring; she recommends docs over decks, linking to live systems (e.g., Jira), and using shared templates/artifacts via product ops.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor read for Superhuman, highlighting speed, inbox workflows, and AI features, with a free trial link.

topics.title: Career acceleration: be known for excellence
topics.summary: JZ’s advice for new PMs: develop a clear “superpower” (e.g., analytics, execution, complex launches) that builds reputation and earns bigger scope; she shares how her strengths evolved across roles.

topics.title: OKRs: focus on qualitative success and ambition
topics.summary: JZ recommends starting with what ‘crushing it’ means qualitatively to avoid fear-driven sandbagging; she prefers ambitious OKRs with clear milestone paths and a culture that doesn’t punish smart risk-taking.

topics.title: WeWork lessons: empathy, layoffs, and over-hiring
topics.summary: JZ recounts leading through WeWork’s 2019 turmoil: building a global team, then navigating layoffs; key takeaways include empathy in leadership and disciplined hiring tied to milestones and real customer needs.

topics.title: Hardest WeWork moment and joining Webflow
topics.summary: JZ shares a personal story about being pregnant during layoffs, choosing to give her role to someone with visa constraints, then interviewing and joining Webflow with 90 days before her child was born.
